Thanks! Will merge after I fixup the tests.

Hi Jesse,

High-level question. Have you considered using the [`Filter` transform](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/Filter.java#L52) and whether that simplifies or maybe even obviates this transform?

E.g., keeping all rows that match a Regex could be

``` java
Filter.byPredicate((String s) -> s.matches("myregex"));
```

Dan

It's when you get into the more complex ones with groups or KVs that it helps. Using KVs gives you a multi-line lambda.

Also that code recreates the Patten object on each call. Quoth the method's docs: `If a pattern is to be used multiple times, compiling it once and reusing it will be more efficient than invoking this method each time.`
LGTM, modulo resolution of pending comments.
R: @bjchambers
I feel like R: @kennknowles is the right choice for this one.
Looks good to me.

More info about why a class is better than a lambda in this case. According to the docs `String.matches` runs like `Pattern.compile(regex).matcher(input).matches()`. The `Pattern.compile` is never reused and ["is less efficient"](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html). If we're doing a million calls, that's a lot.

Cool, taking a look.

At a high level, a few good core string transforms are a good addition to the SDK (versus material for an external library). Regexes do seem as fundamental as `Sum` and certainly `ApproximateQuantiles`. The tricky part is just to hit the sweet spot of the myriad uses for regexes.

Aside from a general :+1: note that`Pattern` does implement `Serializable` so you can always compile it outside the lambda, no?

I think this code hits the basic distributed grep use cases. It doesn't hit the distributed search and replace use cases. I could add that too.

You bring up a good point about things that should be in the SDK and shouldn't. I agree that string transformations should be included.

That said, others will have code to donate that only appeal to a subset. I encourage creating something like [Pig's Piggy Bank](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/PIG/PiggyBank). It a place where you could donate code that doesn't belong in the SDK and doesn't have to go through the various rigors.

The missing piece is state. Obvious routes forward:
1. Add `FlinkStateInternals` to batch at the needed places.
2. Have the runner bail out on non-global windows in batch, which would allow `GroupAlsoByWindow` to be a no-op.

@rangadi can you fix checkstyle errors ? I can do it for you if you prefer.

I think adding `FlinkStateInternals` is the way to go, especially in the long run. We should do the windowing in a `GroupReduceFunction` which is used like this in Flink:

```
DataSet in = ...
in
  .groupBy(<some key>)
  .reduceGroup(<some GroupReduceFunction>)
```

elements are partitioned into key-groups by sorting, then the whole group of elements with the same key is passed to the `GroupReduceFunction`. We would only have to instantiate one `FlinkStateInternals` per group and can discard it afterwards since no more elements with the same key would arrive.
This is a somewhat bigger change, though.
The code looks good to me. Can you just please fix checkstyle errors ?

Agreed with Dan's both points. A source, philosophically, abstracts how to parallelize an input - applying a function to the elements is not part of that. And BoundedSourceTester seems fully redundant with SourceTestUtils (if not, please merge the missing functions into SourceTestUtils instead. If it's not discoverable enough, let's raise that as a separate issue - but it's mentioned in the docs of BoundedSource and on the public documentation page about sources and sinks; please let me know where you would have noticed it, so we can link it there too).
looks good so far, several other pom files that could benefit from this as well

R: @dhalperi

As far as I can see, this has reduced the build time from 15 minutes to 13 minutes (excluding outlays). Not a great win, IMO, with the given complexity. Perhaps we should chat separately if this is worth it.
Thanks @kennknowles, I'll keep it in mind.
We should just continue to find things we can omit. Certainly compile-and-test of 13 minutes is ridiculous for this project.

I didn't dig into too many modules, but `mvn clean install -pl sdks/java/core` went from ~3.5 minutes to ~2 minutes. To understand where the time goes, `mvn test -pl sdks/java/core` takes ~1.5 minutes.

So, taking all timings with a grain of salt, for the SDK this change reduced overall time by ~40% and reduced non-testing time by ~75%. I hope we can improve it further, and make similar improvements to all modules. We should also aim to reduce the testing time. This was a run with default settings, and it looked like `parallel=none` was set. Unless maven is inserting parallelism elsewhere, we should fix this.
